support_summary: ATXN3 directly interacts with and modulates the activity of APE1 (APEX1), a key enzyme in the base excision repair (BER) pathway of DNA.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 interacts with Apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease 1 (APE1), a critical enzyme that processes abasic sites in the DNA base excision repair (BER) pathway.
functions.effect_description: This interaction likely facilitates the DNA repair process, potentially by modulating APE1's endonuclease activity or its recruitment to sites of DNA damage, thereby contributing to the maintenance of genomic integrity.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 interaction with APE1 → Modulation of AP site processing → Efficient repair of single-base DNA damage → Prevention of mutation accumulation
specific_effects: APE1 is the major AP endonuclease in mammalian cells, responsible for cleaving the DNA backbone at abasic sites.
Both ATXN3 and APE1 are involved in the cellular response to oxidative DNA damage.

evidence.paper_title: Oxidative DNA damage is concurrently repaired by base excision repair (BER) and apyrimidinic endonuclease 1 (APE1)-initiated nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) in cortical neurons
The DNA base excision repair protein Ape1/Ref-1 as a therapeutic and chemopreventive target

mechanism: ATXN3 interacts with Apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease 1 (APE1), a critical enzyme that processes abasic sites in the DNA base excision repair (BER) pathway.
effect: This interaction likely facilitates the DNA repair process, potentially by modulating APE1's endonuclease activity or its recruitment to sites of DNA damage, thereby contributing to the maintenance of genomic integrity.
summary: ATXN3 activates APE1 to modulate base excision repair (ber), ultimately affecting prevention of mutation accumulation.

evidence.paper_title: Oxidative DNA damage is concurrently repaired by base excision repair (BER) and apyrimidinic endonuclease 1 (APE1)-initiated nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) in cortical neurons
The DNA base excision repair protein Ape1/Ref-1 as a therapeutic and chemopreventive target
